title: ‚ÄúSlides‚Äù
Slide sources go in the slides/ folder.

Plink
vcftools
BCFtools
Bedtools







Tools installation






Open the terminal from your macOS or windows WSL PC (see pre-course tutorial if you can‚Äôt open terminal)
Make directory & download software files in there

cd --                   # to change location to your home

mkdir -p ~/tools/plink  # make a new directories

cd ~/tools/plink        # move to new directories


wget https://s3.amazonaws.com/plink1-assets/plink_linux_x86_64_20250819.zip  # get the plink with wget command

unzip files

unzip plink_linux_x86_64_20250819.zip

change permission

ll                # to see the lists or contents
chmod +x plink    # permission is changes for execution with +x
ll

activate plink

echo 'export PATH=$PATH:~/tools/plink' >> ~/.bashrc  # activate bash

source ~/.bashrc
this command ensures you can run it from anywhere in the terminal just by typing plink, without needing to specify the full path

check plink activation

plink --version   # it will print version no.

# or 

plink             # it will print a breif & all options

Install vcftools, bcftools, bedtools first see them if tools are installed already or not

vcftools --version
bcftools --version
bedtools --version
If you see error or there is no tools like that, then follow the rest of the commands and execute one by one. It will install tools.
sudo apt install vcftools  # install vcftools at your windows wsl or mac

vcftools --version
sudo apt install bcftools

bcftools --version
sudo apt install bedtools # install vcftools at your windows wsl or mac

bedtools --version

Practical 01 ‚Äî Intro

GAPIT3

rrBLUP







Packages installation







R can be freely downloaded from http://www.r-project.org.
We also recommend the integrated development environment RStudio which is also freely available at http://www.rstudio.com.
GAPIT can currently be installed in several ways.

From source on the internet
From GitHub
From an archive




GAPIT can be loaded with a single funciton.
source("http://zzlab.net/GAPIT/gapit_functions.txt")
Or from GitHub function.
source("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/jiabowang/GAPIT/refs/heads/master/gapit_functions.txt", encoding = "UTF-8")



Installation can also be made from GitHub when the R package devtools is available.
install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("jiabowang/GAPIT", force=TRUE)
library(GAPIT)

or
install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("jiabowang/GAPIT")
library(GAPIT)



GAPIT can be installed from an archive such as *.tar.gz or *.zip archive. An archive can be downloaded from the ‚Äúreleases‚Äù page. If you would like the latest version of GAPIT from the GitHub site you may want to clone it and then build it (this may require Rtools on Windows).
git clone git@github.com:jiabowang/GAPIT.git
R CMD build GAPIT
Once an archive has been obtained it can be installed from a shell, similar to as follows.
R CMD INSTALL GAPIT_3.5.0.9000.tar.gz
Or similarly from within R.
install.packages("GAPIT_3.5.0.9000.tar.gz", repos = NULL, type="source")



Installation of same packages such as ‚Äúmulttest‚Äù and ‚Äúbiobase‚Äù can not be intalled from BiocManager directly. These packages can be downloaded in the Bioconductor website and be installed from local source files.
The website of Bioconductor is here:
https://bioconductor.org/packages/3.19/bioc/
More details please check and ref user manual.



install.packages("ggplot2")
install.packages("rrBLUP")
library("ggplot2")
library("rrBLUP")

Before 1st meeting, you must have Linux/WSL/Unix system (Windows users do need WSL or Unix), R and RStudio in your laptop. If you do not have them, then install them (see the Tutorials links).
We strongly recommend for those not yet familiar with Shell or R to take this opportunity and take the following online tutorials [Shell] & [A (very) short introduction to R.pdf], since those are pre-requisite for the workshop but not mandatory. This will help you to develop your programming skills and we can always learn a few tricks here and there, even if you are already experienced.

title: data_handling_part1
text:
Help in R
There are three ways to get help in R:_ 1. The help() command, which can be abbreviated by ?, 2. The help.search() function, which can be abbreviated by ?? looks for function already installed on your computer, 3. The RSiteSearch() command will open a browser to a searchable database of
questions and answers posted on the R-help mailing list.

help(c)      # or ?c

starting httpd help server ... done

# ??merge    # or help.search(merge)



Data types in R

str(cars)

'data.frame':   50 obs. of  2 variables:
 $ speed: num  4 4 7 7 8 9 10 10 10 11 ...
 $ dist : num  2 10 4 22 16 10 18 26 34 17 ...




Missing Values
In R, missing values are represented by the string NA: We must use the builtin is.na function, which will return TRUE if a value is missing and FALSE otherwise.
Many functions (like mean, min, max, sd, quantile, etc.) accept an na.rm=TRUE argument, that tells the function to remove any missing values before performing the computation:
We just need to remember to always use is.na whenever we are testing to see if a value is a missing value.

x = c(1,4,7,NA,12,19,15,21,20)
mean(x)

[1] NA

mean(x, na.rm=TRUE)

[1] 12.375

is.na(x)

[1] FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE

!is.na(x)

[1]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE


By combining a call to is.na to the logical ‚Äúnot‚Äù operator ! we can filter out missing values in cases where no na.rm= argument is available.


Matrices
A very common way of storing data is in a matrix. A matrix of 4 rows, 3 columns.

mymat = matrix(1:12,4,3)
mymat = matrix(1:12,ncol=3)

To create a matrix by rows instead of by columns, the byrow=TRUE argument can be used:

mymat = matrix(1:12, ncol=3, byrow=TRUE)
mymat

     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]    1    2    3
[2,]    4    5    6
[3,]    7    8    9
[4,]   10   11   12

mymat[4,1]  # element in row=4, col=1

[1] 10

mymat[,1]  # column 1, 

[1]  1  4  7 10

mymat[4,]  # row 4 

[1] 10 11 12

script. author: ‚ÄúF. Isik‚Äù

title: Data_handling (under development)
section: Reasons not reset the working directory
text:
Reasons not reset the working directory

Maybe my working directory is reserved for other files or custom functions I‚Äôve written.
Maybe I‚Äôve been clever about how I store files, and files that do different things are stored in different places
Maybe I work with tons of files and don‚Äôt want to crowd up my working directory with loose files
Maybe I want to reserve the output of R functions like ‚Äúwrite.csv‚Äù for my working directory- input files go elsewhere.

The clever way is to assign the directory of interest to a variable so you don‚Äôt need to type as much let‚Äôs call it wd.

wd<-"C:/Users/auue0001/OneDrive - Sveriges lantbruksuniversitet/slubi/proj/2025/GS_course/website/intro-to-linux-and-R/practicalsexcercise/data/"
wd

[1] "C:/Users/auue0001/OneDrive - Sveriges lantbruksuniversitet/slubi/proj/2025/GS_course/website/intro-to-linux-and-R/practicalsexcercise/data/"


Now the directory containing our file is located in the variable ‚Äòwd‚Äô. When you do a lot of work with R, you want it to be easy to find your files. Use a directory that is easy to find, and a directory structure that makes sense.
For example, organize your files into folders labelled with project names. In this case I want to bring in the dataset Pine_provenance.csv.

title: Data_handling (under development)
text:
Read in a data file
There is an easy way to do this and a more nuanced way to do this. I will cover the nuanced way first.
Let‚Äôs say I don‚Äôt want to reset my working directory.

title: Data_handling (under development)
text:
The source directory
We are going to hold all the filenames in this directory in an object called ‚Äúfiles‚Äù. The function list.files displays the filenames of each file in the directory. I assign the output of this function to the variable‚Äùfiles‚Äù. If I don‚Äôt assign the output to the variable, the results are simply printed to the screen.

files<-list.files(wd)

Let‚Äôs look at the files in the directory. Simply type files and press enter: files
It looks like there are multiple files here of different file types. I am only interested in .csv files Let‚Äôs modify the output of ‚Äúlist.files‚Äù a little bit by giving it the ‚Äúpattern‚Äù argument. We will overwrite the ‚Äúfiles‚Äù object with a new object of the same name,

files<-list.files(wd,pattern="csv")
files

character(0)

title: Data_handling (under development)
text:
Reading data
The easier and less nuanced way to move around the filesystem of your computer using R is to simply reset your working directory This is accomplished via the function setwd().
After I reset the working directory, I can use read.csv without specifying the directory; it‚Äôs now implicit (a global option).

setwd("C:/Users/auue0001/OneDrive - Sveriges lantbruksuniversitet/slubi/proj/2025/GS_course/website/intro-to-linux-and-R/practicals/excercise/")
pine <-read.csv("./data/Pine_provenance.csv")

The red.table and ‚Äôread.csv are two common functions to read data.frames
One shortcoming of vectors and matrices is that they can only hold one mode of data; they don‚Äôt allow us to mix, say, numbers and character strings. But data frames can have different models of data

head(pine)

title: Data_handling (under development)
text:
Subsetting data and summarizing
The subset function requires two arguments: the first is a data frame, the second is the condition that you want to use to create the subset. An optional third argument called select= allows you to specify which of the variables in the data frame you‚Äôre interested in.
Example: subset data with the provenance (origin) number < 12, prov10 <- subset(pine, prov<12).
subset data with two conditions: prov.sub <- subset(pine, prov<11, select = c('prov','height') )
Sort data by height: sort(prov.sub$height, decreasing=TRUE).
Display data summary: summary(pine, c('height','diameter')).

title: Data_handling (under development)
text:
More data summary
We will be using the package ‚Äúdplyr‚Äù to produce some summary tables. This package is particular useful for vectorised operations like grouping and summarising by groups You may need to install this package first. use install.packages("dplyr").

library(dplyr)

First, we check what the ‚Äòstructure‚Äô of the data frame is using str(). This will tell us what kind of variable each column in the data set is considered to be. str(pine)
Notice that treeid is correctly considered a factor variable, but the other factors we want to include in a linear model (female, prov, block in particular) are considered integer (‚Äòint‚Äô) variables (round number), which are a special type of numeric variable. We coerce these variables to be factors with as.factor() function:

pine$female <- as.factor(pine$female) 
pine$prov <- as.factor(pine$prov)
pine$block <- as.factor(pine$block)

Now, we re-check the structure of the data frame to be certain these commands did what we want:

title: Data_handling (under development)
text:
Outlier Detection
Make a scatterplot of height and volume to check for outliers:

plot(x = pine$volume, y = pine$height, 
     xlab = "Volume (cubic inches)", ylab = "Height (feet)",
     main = " ", col = "blue")

title: Data_handling (under development)
text:
Outlier detection using psych package
One way to detect unusual data is to consider how far each data point is from the multivariate centroid of the data. That is, find the squared Mahalanobis distance for each data point and then compare these to the expected values of \(œá^2\). \[D^2 = (x-\mu)'\sigma^{-1}(x-u)\], where \(\sigma\) is the covariance of the x matrix.
Large \(D^2\) values, compared to the expected Chi Square values indicate an unusual response pattern. The mahalanobis function in stats does not handle missing data.
This produces a Q-Q (quantle-quantile) plot with the n most extreme data points labeled. We combine the outliers with the data frame and plot it with the outliers. Outliers are highlighted in blue. bad=5 labels the worst five values.

library(psych)
d2 <- outlier(pine[,7:9], bad = 5, na.rm = TRUE)







sat.d2 <- data.frame(pine[,7:9], d2)
pairs.panels(sat.d2,bg=c("lightgreen","blue")[(d2 > 25)+1],pch=21)

Linux commands

GAPIT3
ggplot2

Packages installation







R can be freely downloaded from http://www.r-project.org.
We also recommend the integrated development environment RStudio which is also freely available at http://www.rstudio.com.
GAPIT can currently be installed in several ways.

From source on the internet
From GitHub
From an archive




GAPIT can be loaded with a single funciton.
source("http://zzlab.net/GAPIT/gapit_functions.txt")
Or from GitHub function.
source("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/jiabowang/GAPIT/refs/heads/master/gapit_functions.txt", encoding = "UTF-8")



Installation can also be made from GitHub when the R package devtools is available.
install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("jiabowang/GAPIT", force=TRUE)
library(GAPIT)
or
install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("jiabowang/GAPIT")
library(GAPIT)



GAPIT can be installed from an archive such as *.tar.gz or *.zip archive. An archive can be downloaded from the ‚Äúreleases‚Äù page. If you would like the latest version of GAPIT from the GitHub site you may want to clone it and then build it (this may require Rtools on Windows).
git clone git@github.com:jiabowang/GAPIT.git
R CMD build GAPIT
Once an archive has been obtained it can be installed from a shell, similar to as follows.
R CMD INSTALL GAPIT_3.5.0.9000.tar.gz
Or similarly from within R.
install.packages("GAPIT_3.5.0.9000.tar.gz", repos = NULL, type="source")



Installation of same packages such as ‚Äúmulttest‚Äù and ‚Äúbiobase‚Äù can not be intalled from BiocManager directly. These packages can be downloaded in the Bioconductor website and be installed from local source files.
The website of Bioconductor is here:
https://bioconductor.org/packages/3.19/bioc/
More details please check and ref user manual.







install packs
install.packages("ggplot2")
install.packages("rrBLUP")
attach the packs
library("ggplot2")
library("rrBLUP")

Solution & explanation






üìÅ File Setup
Download or place these files (üìÅ data_4_linux) in your working directory:

example.vcf: VCF file with genotype data
regions.bed: BED file with genomic regions
plink_data.ped and plink_data.map: Input files for Plink



üîπ vcftools

Calculate allele frequencies

vcftools --vcf example.vcf --freq

--vcf example.vcf: Specifies the input VCF file.
--freq: Calculates allele frequencies for each variant.
Output: out.frq (or use --out to name it).


Filter variants by minor allele frequency

vcftools --vcf example.vcf --maf 0.05 --recode --out filtered_maf

--maf 0.05: Filters out variants with MAF < 0.05.
--recode: Outputs a new VCF file with only the filtered variants.
--out filtered_maf: Prefix for output files.


Count missing data per individual

vcftools --vcf example.vcf --missing-indv --out missing_data

--missing-indv: Calculates missing genotype rates per individual.
Output: missing_data.imiss



üîπ bcftools

View VCF header

bcftools view -h example.vcf

-h: Displays only the header lines of the VCF file.


Filter variants by quality

bcftools view -i 'QUAL>30' example.vcf -o highqual.vcf

-i 'QUAL>30': Includes only variants with quality > 30.
-o highqual.vcf: Output file name.


Convert VCF to BCF

bcftools view -O b -o output.bcf example.vcf

-O b: Output format is BCF (binary VCF).
-o output.bcf: Output file name.



üîπ bedtools

Intersect VCF with BED regions

bedtools intersect -a example.vcf -b regions.bed > vcf_in_regions.vcf

-a: First file (VCF) to compare.
-b: Second file (BED) with regions of interest.
>: Redirects output to a new file.


Count intersected variants

grep -v "^#" vcf_in_regions.vcf | wc -l

grep -v "^#": Removes header lines.
wc -l: Counts the number of remaining lines (i.e., variants).



üîπ Plink

Calculate allele frequencies

plink --file plink_data --freq --out plink_freq

--file plink_data: Uses plink_data.ped and plink_data.map.
--freq: Calculates allele frequencies.
--out plink_freq: Output prefix.


Check missingness

plink --file plink_data --missing --out plink_missing

--missing: Calculates missing genotype rates per individual and per SNP.
Output: .imiss and .lmiss files.

title: 1. Packages needed for R modules:
text:
GAPIT can be installed from an archive such as *.tar.gz or *.zip archive. An archive can be downloaded from the ‚Äúreleases‚Äù page. If you would like the latest version of GAPIT from the GitHub site you may want to clone it and then build it (this may require Rtools on Windows).
git clone git@github.com:jiabowang/GAPIT.git
R CMD build GAPIT
Once an archive has been obtained it can be installed from a shell, similar to as follows.
R CMD INSTALL GAPIT_3.5.0.9000.tar.gz
Or similarly from within R.
install.packages("GAPIT_3.5.0.9000.tar.gz", repos = NULL, type="source")

title: 1. Packages needed for R modules:
text:
Installation of same packages such as ‚Äúmulttest‚Äù and ‚Äúbiobase‚Äù can not be intalled from BiocManager directly. These packages can be downloaded in the Bioconductor website and be installed from local source files.
The website of Bioconductor is here:
https://bioconductor.org/packages/3.19/bioc/

title: Tools or packages needed for R modules:
text: GWAS methods include: General Linear Model(GLM),Mixed Linear Model(MLM),compressed Mixed Linear Model(CMLM),SUPER, FarmCPU, MLMM, and BLINK. Users can use model=‚ÄúGLM‚Äù to select method.

title: Tools or packages needed for R modules:
text: GS methods include: gBLUP, cBLUP, sBLUP, and GAGBLUP. Besides GAGBLUP, all GS methods could be seleted by using model=‚ÄúgBLUP‚Äù.

title: Intro to Linux & R
text:
Intended Learning Outcomes
By the end of the day1, participants will be able to:
Unix/Linux

Describe CLI, Linux shell, tools
Install and verify the functionality of key genomics tools: Plink, vcftools, BCFtools, and Bedtools.
Navigate the Unix/Linux environment, including creating directories, moving between locations, and managing files.

R

Install and load essential R packages for genomic analysis: GAPIT3, ggplot2, and rrBLUP.
Set working directories
Load and explore data in R, including reading tables and data frames.

title: Intro to Linux & R
text:
Learning Activities
To achieve the above outcomes, participants will:
Unix/Linux:

Read Linux, CLI, Shell materials (pre-course materials, 1st meeting).
Follow guided installation steps for Plink, vcftools, BCFtools, and Bedtools on their systems (pre-course, 1st meeting).
Run basic Unix commands to create directories, navigate folders, and manage files (1st meeting).

R:

Read and follow R & RStudio materials
Explore data structure, set working directories(pre-course, 1st meeting).
Install R packages and verify functionality by loading them in R(1st meeting).
Load data into R, inspect it using both from RStudio and by functions (1st meeting).

man ls 
Note: press on Q keyboard button to exit
classify list (files or folders):
ls -F 
ls -F ./
Here -F is an option and ./ is an argument

print the author of each file:
ls -la

pwd

mkdir my_tools
multiple sub folders at once:

cd my_tools

look at the texts before the $ sign in the terminal

pwd

tools installation in Linux






cd --               # be in your home directory

cd my_tools/plink   # be in your plink directory
We use wget command for this see all version here
wget https://s3.amazonaws.com/plink1-assets/plink_linux_x86_64_20250819.zip


use unzip command,
unzip plink_linux_x86_64.zip
to know more unzip --help



use chmod command
chmod +x plink
to know more chmod --help



(optional but recommended)
echo 'export PATH=$PATH:~/my_tools/plink' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc
this command ensures you can run it from anywhere in the terminal just by typing plink, without needing to specify the full path.
Explanation: - echo = print what is after it

>> = is a shell operator used to append text to a file.
~ = home/username
.bashrc is a configuration file in your home directory that runs every time you start a new terminal session (specifically for Bash shell).

PLINK v1.9.0-b.7.11 64-bit (19 Aug 2025)

From GitHub

Plink
vcftools
BCFtools
Bedtools







Tools installation






Open the terminal from your macOS or windows WSL PC (see pre-course tutorial if you can‚Äôt open terminal)
Make directory & download software files in there

cd --                   # to change location to your home

mkdir -p ~/tools/plink  # make a new directories

cd ~/tools/plink        # move to new directories


wget https://s3.amazonaws.com/plink1-assets/plink_linux_x86_64_20250819.zip  # get the plink with wget command

unzip files

unzip plink_linux_x86_64_20250819.zip

change permission

ll                # to see the lists or contents
chmod +x plink    # permission is changes for execution with +x
ll

activate plink

echo 'export PATH=$PATH:~/tools/plink' >> ~/.bashrc  # activate bash

source ~/.bashrc
this command ensures you can run it from anywhere in the terminal just by typing plink, without needing to specify the full path

check plink activation

plink --version   # it will print version no.

# or 

plink             # it will print a breif & all options

Install vcftools, bcftools, bedtools first see them if tools are installed already or not

vcftools --version
bcftools --version
bedtools --version
If you see error or there is no tools like that, then follow the rest of the commands and execute one by one. It will install tools.
sudo apt install vcftools  # install vcftools at your windows wsl or mac

vcftools --version
sudo apt install bcftools

bcftools --version
sudo apt install bedtools # install vcftools at your windows wsl or mac

bedtools --version
